objectives.description: Explain what credit scores are, how they are calculated, and why they matter for your financial future.
Break down the five components of a FICO score and understand the weight each factor carries in your overall score.
Recognize specific actions that help improve your credit score and behaviors that can damage it significantly.
Connect credit score concepts to real-world situations including housing, employment, insurance, and loan rates.

terms.definition: A numerical representation of your creditworthiness, typically ranging from 300 to 850, used by lenders to assess risk.
terms.example: 300-579: Poor ‚Ä¢ 580-669: Fair ‚Ä¢ 670-739: Good ‚Ä¢ 740-799: Very Good ‚Ä¢ 800-850: Excellent

terms.definition: The most widely used credit scoring model in the United States, created by the Fair Isaac Corporation and used by 90% of lenders.
terms.example: Lenders use FICO to determine loan approval, interest rates, and credit limits for mortgages, auto loans, and credit cards.

terms.definition: A detailed record of your credit history, including all borrowing habits, payment history, and current debt levels.
terms.example: Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion each maintain your credit report. Free annual access at AnnualCreditReport.com

terms.definition: The percentage of your available credit that you're currently using. Lower is better‚Äîexperts recommend staying under 30%.
terms.example: $3,000 credit limit with $900 balance = 30% utilization. Keep it below $900 for optimal score impact.

leftPanel.title: Five Factors, Different Weights
paragraphs: Your FICO score isn't random‚Äîit's calculated from five specific categories of your credit behavior.
Understanding these weights helps you prioritize which behaviors matter most for building excellent credit.

infoCard.title: Key Insight:
items: Pay bills on time = 35% of your score
Keep balances low = 30% of your score

rightColumn.title: ‚úÖ Soft Inquiries
items: Check as often as you want!

leftPanel.title: Beyond Just Loan Approvals
paragraphs: Your credit score influences far more than just whether you qualify for a credit card or loan. It affects:
Housing: Landlords check credit before approving rental applications. Poor credit may require larger deposits or co-signers.
Employment: Some employers review credit as part of background checks, especially for financial positions.
Insurance: Many insurers use credit-based scores to determine your premiums for auto and home insurance.

highlightBox.text: � Your credit score is your financial reputation‚Äîit follows you everywhere.

infoCard.title: Good Credit Benefits:
items: Lower interest rates on all loans

content.headerTitle: The Real Cost of Credit Scores

layoutData.title: Score Differences = Dollar Differences
paragraphs: The difference between a "fair" credit score and an "excellent" credit score can cost you tens of thousands of dollars over your lifetime. Here's how it plays out on a $300,000 mortgage:

keyPoint.text: üí∞ A 100-point score difference could cost you $94,680 in extra interest on just one mortgage!

leftPanel.title: Smart Habits Start Now
paragraphs: Building excellent credit isn't complicated‚Äîit just requires consistent good habits over time.
The earlier you start, the longer your credit history and the better your score potential.
DO:
‚Ä¢ Pay every bill on time, every time
‚Ä¢ Keep credit utilization under 30%
‚Ä¢ Keep old accounts open
‚Ä¢ Check your credit report annually

content.headerTitle: Why This Matters for Your Future

layoutData.title: Your Credit Score = Your Financial Foundation
paragraphs: Every major financial milestone in your life will be affected by your credit score. The habits you build now determine your options later.
bulletPoints: First Apartment: Landlords require credit checks. Good credit = approved, poor credit = denied or high deposits
First Car Loan: Interest rates vary dramatically based on score. Could mean $50+/month difference
Student Loan Rates: Private student loans use credit scores to set interest rates
First Home: Mortgage approval and rates heavily depend on your credit history
Career Opportunities: Many employers check credit for positions involving money or trust
Insurance Costs: Auto and home insurance premiums often factor in credit scores

keyPoint.text: üéØ Building credit is a marathon, not a sprint. Start good habits now and maintain them consistently.

leftPanel.title: The Digital Age of Credit
paragraphs: Credit monitoring has never been easier‚Äîmany banks and apps now offer free credit score tracking.
You can check your score weekly without any impact (soft inquiry). This helps you:

highlightBox.text: � Most major banks and credit card companies offer free score access to customers.

scenario.name: Jason's Hard Inquiry Mistake in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Jason was shopping for his first credit card. He thought he'd compare offers by applying for three different cards within one month.
What he didn't realize: Each application created a hard inquiry on his credit report. His score dropped 25 points‚Äîfrom 680 to 655.
Now he's having trouble getting approved for an apartment lease because his score dropped below the landlord's minimum requirement of 660. His dream apartment went to someone else.

scenario.name: Sophia's Credit History Setback in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Sophia wanted to simplify her finances, so she decided to close her oldest credit card account‚Äîone she'd had for 8 years but rarely used.
The unintended consequences:
Her score dropped 40 points, affecting her ability to qualify for a low-interest auto loan.

takeaways.title: Payment History Is King
takeaways.description: 35% of your score comes from paying on time. One late payment can drop your score significantly.

takeaways.title: Keep Utilization Low
takeaways.description: Use less than 30% of your available credit. Lower utilization = higher score potential.

takeaways.title: Age Matters
takeaways.description: Keep old accounts open to maintain credit history length. Don't close cards unnecessarily.

takeaways.title: Credit Affects Everything
takeaways.description: Housing, employment, insurance, and interest rates all depend on your credit score.
